instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: this machine was powering on even after a cola spilled on it. i decided to clean it for safe measure and now it doesn't power up. i found short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>. i'm new to the touchbar logic boards. i looked at the schematic but i'm still lost as to which chip creates <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> and is it safe to inject 3 volts since this rail goes directly to the cpu

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Voltage comes out from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
And can be PCH, or <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> fault.

If is not really short, then is possible to be crap under one of it; put good flux and heat for test.
If is a very low value (000-003), you can try injecting voltage.

There are also 2-3 caps which you can check fiest.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: i have removed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from the board and <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> still has very low resistance to ground. is this value coming from <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>? <RESISTOR>R1401</RESISTOR> has very low resistance on both sides

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1401</RESISTOR> has 1M, so cannot generate such fail.
But if you have short to ground in two different points of PCH (VCCRTC and INTRUDER) that points to bad PCH 100%...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: the machine was booting fine. all i did was ultrasonic the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"put good [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/amtech-nc-559-v2-30-cc-16160.html"]flux[/URL] and heat for test."
But I doubt it will help in this case...

"all i did was [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/crest-p500h-45.html"]ultrasonic[/URL] the board"
No sweep function???
How many minutes left the board in the UC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: removed the caps from the rail and i check them then i put them back and the short went away. maybe the heat got to the pch

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: well i'm waiting on a stencil that i  ordered to put <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> back on the board but i'm confident that the short was the issue

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0v unless i heat up the pch area a little. i guess this thing needs a reflow

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C7934</CAPACITOR> must've moved off the pad when i removed the pmic.  that was the issue
